questions.text: A patient presented with the X-ray. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Miliary TB

 

Miliary tuberculosis (TB) is characterized by the presence of numerous small nodules that are uniformly distributed throughout the lungs. These nodules are millet-seed-sized, giving a "miliary" appearance on the chest X-ray. The image provided shows these numerous tiny nodules distributed evenly across both lung fields, which is classic for miliary TB.

 

Miliary TB occurs when a large number of Mycobacterium tuberculosis organisms disseminate through the bloodstream and lodge in multiple organs, most commonly the lungs. The small size and uniformity of the nodules in the X-ray are key diagnostic features.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchogenic carcinoma: This typically presents as a mass lesion on an X-ray, which may cause collapse of the surrounding lung tissue. The absence of a clear mass lesion on the X-ray rules out bronchogenic carcinoma as the most likely diagnosis.

 

Option B. Aspergilloma: Aspergilloma is characterized by the presence of a fungal ball within a pre-existing lung cavity. On an X-ray, this would appear as a cavity with a round or oval density within it, often surrounded by an air crescent, known as the "monad sign" or "air crescent sign."

 

 

Option C. Lung abscess: A lung abscess is typically seen as a cavity with an air-fluid level, where the top of the cavity shows air and the bottom contains fluid. The X-ray provided does not show such a cavity with an air-fluid level, making this option less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Miliary TB presents with numerous small, uniformly distributed nodules on a chest X-ray, resembling millet seeds. This pattern is a hallmark of disseminated tuberculosis.

questions.text: A patient presented with recurrent Raynaud’s phenomenon. She also complained of thickening of skin in the hands and difficulty in swallowing. What is the diagnosis and immunofluorescence pattern shown? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anti-centromere pattern; Systemic sclerosis

 

The combination of Raynaud's phenomenon, skin thickening limited to hands (acral areas), and difficulty swallowing points to limited systemic sclerosis (formerly called CREST syndrome). The immunofluorescence image shows a characteristic centromeric pattern with discrete speckles corresponding to centromeres in dividing cells. Anti-centromere antibodies are specifically associated with limited systemic sclerosis, making this pattern diagnostic in this clinical context.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nuclear pattern; SLE: Incorrect. The pattern shown is centromeric, not nuclear.

 

Option B. Homogeneous pattern; SLE: Incorrect. Homogeneous patterns are produced by anti-histone and anti-dsDNA antibodies, seen in SLE or drug-induced lupus.

 

Option C. Speckled pattern; Systemic sclerosis: Incorrect. While speckled patterns can be seen in systemic sclerosis (particularly with anti-Scl-70 antibodies in diffuse disease), the image shows a centromeric pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-centromere antibodies producing a centromeric immunofluorescence pattern are specifically associated with limited systemic sclerosis, particularly when presenting with Raynaud's phenomenon and acral skin thickening.

choices.text: Blunt object with high force doesn’t stimulate nociceptors
Pinching with serrated object stimulate mechanoceptors but doesn’t cause pain
Sharp pain sensation is carried by type C nerve fiber

questions.text: Mechanical nociceptors and its response to a probe with blunt object, pin prick and tooth forceps with serration is recorded as a output of a force transducer coupled to the stimulator. What will you infer from a given diagram? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blunt object with high force doesn't stimulate nociceptors

 

Blunt Object:

 

  • Does not produce action potentials in nociceptors
  • Activates mechanoreceptors without triggering pain sensation
  • High force does not necessarily stimulate nociceptive receptors

 

Pin Prick:

 

  • Produces clear action potentials
  • Stimulates nociceptors
  • Sharp stimuli trigger pain receptors

 

Serrated Forceps:

 

  • Produces multiple action potentials
  • Stimulates both mechanoreceptors and nociceptors
  • Causes significant pain response

 

Sharp pain is typically carried by A-delta fibers

 

Slower, diffuse pain is carried by C fibers

 

Nociceptors respond to potentially tissue-damaging stimuli

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nociceptors (pain receptors) respond differentially to various mechanical stimuli - they are activated by sharp objects and pinching/pressure that can potentially damage tissue, but not by blunt pressure even with high force. Fast, sharp pain is transmitted via A-delta fibers, while slow, dull pain is transmitted via C fibers.

questions.text: A baby assessed 5 minutes after birth, is found to be cyanosed with irregular gasping respiration. Heart rate is 60 beats/min, and a grimace is seen with some flexion of extremities. The Apgar score for this newborn is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4

 

 

In this baby:

 

  • Color, blue - score 0
  • Heart rate, <100 beats/min - score 1
  • Grimace- score 1
  • Some flexion of the extremities - score 1
  • Irregular respiration - score 1

 

Thus the total score is 4.

 

Apgar score is not used to guide resuscitation, and resuscitation must be initiated before the 1-minute score. The change of score at sequential time points following birth reflects how well the baby is responding to resuscitative efforts.

 

A total score of 10 indicates that the infant is in the best possible condition. An infant with a score of 0-3 requires immediate resuscitation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An Apgar score is calculated based on five criteria, each ranging from 0 to 2. A score of 0-3 indicates severe distress, 4-6 indicates moderate difficulty, and 7-10 indicates that the newborn is in good health. The described baby, with a total score of 4, requires close monitoring and possibly further medical intervention.

questions.text: Which law states that the amount of pressure exerted by a gas in a mixture is proportional to the percentage of the gas in the mixture? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Dalton's law

 

Explanation: 

 

Dalton's law states that in a gas mixture, each individual gas exerts a partial pressure that is directly proportional to its percentage composition in the mixture. The formula PP = % Gas × Total pressure directly reflects Dalton's law, where each gas contributes to the total atmospheric pressure based on its fractional concentration. For example, at sea level with atmospheric pressure of 760 mmHg, oxygen (21%) exerts 160 mmHg, nitrogen (79%) exerts 600 mmHg, and CO₂ (0.04%) exerts 0.3 mmHg - each proportional to their respective percentages.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Graham's law - This law relates to the rate of diffusion of gases being inversely proportional to the square root of their molecular weights, not about pressure relationships in gas mixtures.
  • Option C. Henry's law - Henry's law specifically states that "gases that dissolve in the blood only they can generate the partial pressure in the blood." This law governs gas solubility in liquids, not the pressure exerted by gases in mixtures.
  • Option D. Boyle's law - Boyle's law is defined as P ∝ 1/V (pressure inversely proportional to volume). This law describes the relationship between pressure and volume of a gas at constant temperature, not the pressure contribution of individual gases in a mixture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dalton's law is fundamental to understanding respiratory gas exchange, as it explains how each respiratory gas (O₂, CO₂, N₂) contributes its specific partial pressure to the total atmospheric pressure based on its percentage composition.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with post-transcriptional modification? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glycosylation

 

The correct answer is Glycosylation. Glycosylation is a process where sugars are added to proteins or lipids, but it occurs in the endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi apparatus, primarily during and after translation, not during post-transcriptional modifications. Post-transcriptional modifications occur to RNA molecules after they have been transcribed from DNA but before they are translated into proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methylation: Methylation in the context of RNA processing involves the addition of a methyl group, often to the 5' end of the RNA as part of the capping process. For example, a 7-methylguanosine cap is added to the 5' end of the RNA to protect it from degradation and assist in ribosome binding during translation.

 

Option B. Endonuclease cleavage: This is part of the splicing process where introns are removed from the pre-mRNA. Endonucleases cut within the nucleotide sequence, helping to remove non-coding sequences (introns) from the RNA transcript.

 

Option C. Capping: This process involves adding a modified guanine nucleotide (7-methylguanosine) to the 5' end of the RNA. This cap protects the RNA from degradation and is essential for the initiation of translation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycosylation is not a post-transcriptional modification. Post-transcriptional modifications include processes like capping, methylation, and splicing, which are critical for the maturation of mRNA before it is translated into protein.

choices.text: Triangle of death and circle of death
Triangle of doom and circle of death
Triangle of doom medially and triangle of pain laterally
Triangle of doom laterally and triangle of pain medially

questions.text: The Trapezoid of Disaster includes: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Triangle of doom medially and triangle of pain laterally

 

Explanation:

 

During laparoscopic hernia repair, the surgeon must navigate important anatomical landmarks in the inguinal region. The "Trapezoid of Disaster" contains two important triangles that require careful attention during mesh placement. The Triangle of Doom is bounded medially by the vas deferens and laterally by the testicular vessels, containing the external iliac vessels and genital branch of genitofemoral nerve. The Triangle of Pain is located lateral to this, bounded medially by testicular vessels and laterally by the iliopubic tract, containing the femoral nerve, anterior cutaneous nerve of thigh, and lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: "Triangle of death" is anatomically known as the triangle of “doom”.
  • Option B: "Triangle of doom and circle of death" do not form a trapezoid of disaster.
  • Option D: This reverses the correct orientation. The Triangle of Doom is medial and the Triangle of Pain is lateral, not the opposite.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Triangle of Doom contains vital vascular structures (external iliac vessels) while the Triangle of Pain contains important nerves (femoral nerve, cutaneous nerves). Accurate identification of these anatomical landmarks is crucial to prevent iatrogenic injury during laparoscopic hernia repair.

questions.text: A newborn baby with feeble lower limb pulses and bounding upper limb pulses? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) COA (Coarctation of the Aorta)

 

In coarctation of the aorta (COA), there is a narrowing of the aorta, which is the main artery that carries blood from the heart to the rest of the body. This narrowing obstructs blood flow to the lower part of the body. As a result, there is reduced blood flow to the lower limbs, causing feeble pulses in the lower limbs. Meanwhile, the upper body and limbs experience higher blood pressure and bounding pulses due to the increased pressure load.

 

An X-ray of a patient with coarctation of the aorta may show the "figure of 3" sign, indicative of the abnormal aortic shape due to the narrowing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TGA (Transposition of the Great Arteries): In TGA, the major arteries are reversed, causing severe cyanosis. The X-ray shows an "egg on side" appearance, but this condition does not cause differential limb pulses.

 

Option C. TOF (Tetralogy of Fallot): This condition involves four heart defects that cause cyanosis and a "boot-shaped" heart on X-ray, not differential limb pulses.

 

Option D. Ebstein anomaly: This is a congenital heart defect affecting the tricuspid valve and the right side of the heart, leading to a "box-shaped" heart on X-ray, but it does not cause differential pulses between the upper and lower limbs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coarctation of the aorta (COA) is characterized by feeble lower limb pulses and bounding upper limb pulses due to aortic narrowing.

questions.text: Which Biochemical method is exploited for monoclonal antibody production by hybridoma technique?  (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Purine salvage pathway

 

Hybridoma technology → common methods used to produce monoclonal antibodies

 

In this process, antibody-producing B-lymphocytes are isolated from mice after immunizing the mice with specific antigen and are fused with immortal myeloma cell lines to form hybrid cells, called hybridoma cell lines.

 

 

  • Even the most efficient fusion method will give only 1 to 2% of fused and viable hybridoma cells.
  • Hybridoma selection involve screening of the fused cells from the unfused cells. It is done using HAT media (a selection media).
  • HAT medium contains Hypoxanthine-Aminopterin-Thymidine. The trick is that Aminopterin inhibits DHFR. So, it inhibits de-novo purine synthesis. Inhibition of DHFR also inhibits conversion of dUMP to dTMP.
  • Salvage pathway will occur, but only in B-cells, not myeloma cells. Myeloma cells are deficient in HGPRT .
  • Hypoxanthine and deoxythymidine allow cells with functional hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT) genes to survive through salvage pathways.
  • Due to a limited life span, unfused B cells perish within a few days.
  • Unfused malignant neoplastic cells die as a result of the lack of HGPRT gene
  • Therefore, the remaining viable cells left in the media are the hybrid cells; these hybrid cells have the ability to grow and divide on HAT media because they have functional HGPRT gene from B lymphocytes

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycolytic pathway: This pathway is involved in the breakdown of glucose to pyruvate for energy production and is not specifically exploited in hybridoma technology for monoclonal antibody production.

 

Option B. Pentose Phosphate pathway: This pathway generates NADPH and ribose-5-phosphate for nucleotide synthesis but is not the key pathway exploited in the hybridoma technique.

 

Option C. Kreb’s cycle: This cycle is part of cellular respiration and energy production but is not directly involved in the selection process of hybridoma cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The purine salvage pathway is critical in hybridoma technology for monoclonal antibody production, enabling the selection of viable hybridoma cells in HAT medium.

questions.text: Which touch receptors are primarily involved in two-point discrimination?  (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Meissner’s corpuscle

 

Explanation

 

Meissner's corpuscles are the primary receptors involved in two-point discrimination. These receptors mediate fine touch and two-point discrimination while also sensing low frequency vibration. They provide excellent spatial discrimination with minimum distinguishable distances of 1-3 mm on fingertips and lips. Meissner corpuscles are the most abundant touch receptors in glabrous (non-hairy) skin, particularly in areas where tactile discrimination is most critical.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Merkel's disc - While Merkel cells contribute to discrimination of edges and points, they primarily function to detect sustained pressure. They're important for sensing texture and form but are not the primary receptors for two-point discrimination.
  • Option B. Ruffini's end organ - Ruffini endings are slowly adapting mechanoreceptors that sense stretch and sustained pressure. These receptors respond to tissue deformation and are not specialized for the fine spatial discrimination required for two-point testing.
  • Option C. Pacinian corpuscle - Pacinian corpuscles detect high frequency vibration and deep pressure. Located deeper in the dermis and having larger receptive fields, they're unsuitable for fine spatial discrimination tasks like two-point discrimination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meissner's corpuscles, concentrated in the fingertips and other areas requiring fine discrimination, are specialized for detecting separate points in close proximity, making them the primary receptors responsible for two-point discrimination.

questions.text: Decreased sexual maturity and hypogonadism seen with deficiency of: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zinc

 

Zinc is an essential trace element involved in numerous aspects of cellular metabolism. It plays a vital role in immune function, protein synthesis, wound healing, DNA synthesis, and cell division. Zinc is also crucial for normal growth and development during pregnancy, childhood, and adolescence, and it is necessary for the proper functioning of taste and smell.

 

Features of Zinc Deficiency:

 

  • Decreased Sexual Maturity: Zinc deficiency in children and adolescents can lead to growth retardation and delayed sexual maturation, particularly hypogonadism in males.
  • Hypogonadism: This condition is characterized by the underdevelopment of primary or secondary sexual characteristics, such as the testes in males, leading to delayed or absent puberty.
  • Impaired Immune Function: Zinc deficiency can result in an increased susceptibility to infections.
  • Other Symptoms: Include hair loss, diarrhea, delayed wound healing, and eye and skin lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Copper: Deficiency can lead to anemia (microcytic, hypochromic), neutropenia, bone abnormalities, and neurological issues such as peripheral neuropathy and subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord.

 

Option C. Selenium: Deficiency can cause Keshan disease (a type of cardiomyopathy) and Kashin-Beck disease (a type of osteoarthropathy).

 

Option D. Iron: Deficiency is commonly associated with microcytic, hypochromic anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zinc deficiency is associated with decreased sexual maturity and hypogonadism, particularly in male children, and is a common nutritional deficiency in developing countries. It is also linked to impaired growth, immune dysfunction, and delayed wound healing.

questions.text: Milkman’s fracture is a type of? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Pseudofracture

 

Milkman's fracture is a type of pseudofracture found in bone softening disorders such as osteomalacia. These are not true fractures but rather indentations of the cortex due to arterial pulsations. They are also known as Looser's Zone or Umbauzanon. Milkman fractures commonly occur in the neck of femur (NOF) and pubic rami, appearing as radiolucent zones at sites of stress in radiographic imaging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clavicular fracture - Milkman's fracture is unrelated to a specific clavicular injury. While pseudofractures can occur in various bones, they are most commonly found in weight-bearing areas like the pubic rami and femoral neck in patients with underlying bone softening disorders.

 

Option C. Humeral fracture - Milkman's fracture is not a type of humeral fracture. Pseudofractures characteristically appear at sites where major blood vessels cross bone, creating pressure points that lead to cortical indentation.

 

Option D. Metacarpal fracture - Milkman's fracture does not refer to metacarpal injuries. These pseudofractures typically affect the axial skeleton and weight-bearing long bones in conditions like osteomalacia, hyperparathyroidism, and neurofibromatosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Milkman's fracture represents a pseudofracture (Looser's Zone) seen in bone softening disorders, primarily osteomalacia, appearing as cortical indentations at sites of arterial pulsation, commonly in the femoral neck and pubic rami.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with an ulcerative lesion noted near the nose/medical canthus. What is the probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Basal cell carcinoma 

 

  • The patient's presentation with an ulcerative lesion near the nose/medial canthus with rolled out edges is a basal cell carcinoma. 

 

This is the most common type of skin cancer, often appearing in sun-exposed areas such as the face. BCC frequently presents as a pearly bump with telangiectatic vessels or as a flat, flesh-colored or brown scar-like lesion. Ulceration is common in neglected or advanced BCC, particularly near critical areas like the nose and eyes, where it can cause significant local destruction. Given its common presentation and the description provided, BCC is a very likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lentigo Maligna Melanoma: This is a type of melanoma that typically occurs on sun-exposed areas of the skin, particularly the face and the arms, in older adults. It begins as a patch that darkens, enlarges, and sometimes becomes nodular, indicating progression to melanoma. It's less common for lentigo maligna to present initially as an ulcerative lesion, making this a less likely diagnosis.

 

Option C. Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC): SCC is a type of skin cancer that can also appear on sun-exposed skin and may develop from a pre-existing actinic keratosis. It can be more aggressive than BCC and typically presents as a thick, rough, scaly patch that can bleed if bumped. It can ulcerate but often has a more rapid growth compared to BCC.

 

Option D. Nevus: A nevus is a common skin growth (mole), which can be present from birth or appear during childhood or young adulthood. While most nevi are benign, changes in their appearance, such as ulceration, require evaluation to rule out malignant transformation, such as into melanoma.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Given the description of an ulcerative lesion near critical areas like the nose and medial canthus, Basal Cell Carcinoma is the most probable diagnosis due to its frequent occurrence in these regions and its tendency to ulcerate. Treatment typically involves surgical excision, and in some cases, topical or systemic therapy may be considered.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presented with left facial weakness. Routine lab workup was normal. What is the next best step in management? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Corticosteroids

 

The presentation of left facial weakness with normal routine lab workup suggests Bell's palsy, an idiopathic condition characterized by sudden onset of unilateral lower motor neuron facial paralysis. Bell's palsy is a diagnosis of exclusion and is the most common cause of unilateral facial paralysis.

 

Corticosteroids: The first-line treatment for Bell's palsy is corticosteroids. They are most effective when started within 72 hours of symptom onset. Early treatment with corticosteroids can significantly improve the chances of complete recovery. A typical regimen is prednisolone or prednisone.

 

Dosage: Prednisone 60-80 mg per day for 5-7 days, followed by a taper over the next 5-7 days.

 

Note – In the severity grading system, House-Brackmann grading, if the patient has Grade 4 or Grade 5 severity, consider adding antivirals such as acyclovir or valacyclovir.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acyclovir: Although acyclovir or other antiviral agents like valacyclovir are sometimes used, their benefit is less clear. They may be considered in severe cases of Bell's palsy, particularly when there is a suspicion of herpes simplex virus involvement, but they are not the primary treatment.

 

Dosage: Valacyclovir 1 gram TID for 7 days or acyclovir 400 mg five times a day for 7-10 days.

 

Note - Valacyclovir has superior bioavailability, superior efficacy, and lower side effects compared to acyclovir.

 

Option C. Antibiotics: There is no role for antibiotics in the treatment of Bell's palsy as it is not caused by a bacterial infection.

 

Option D. Physiotherapy: While physiotherapy, including facial exercises and eye protection measures, can be supportive, it is not the primary treatment and should be considered an adjunct to corticosteroid therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best initial management for a patient with Bell's palsy is corticosteroid therapy. Early administration within 72 hours of symptom onset greatly enhances the likelihood of complete recovery. Antivirals may be added in severe cases, but they are not the mainstay of treatment.

questions.text: Pseudo P pulmonale is seen in which electrolyte abnormality? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hypokalemia

 

Pseudo P pulmonale, characterized by exaggerated amplitude in the P wave, can be observed on an ECG in the context of hypokalemia. This electrolyte disturbance affects cardiac electrophysiology, leading to various changes including prolonged QT interval, presence of U waves, T wave flattening or inversion, and sometimes pseudo-infarction patterns, which can mimic myocardial infarction.

 

Hypokalemia can result in these distinct ECG changes due to its influence on cellular membrane potentials in cardiac cells, which alters the normal propagation of electrical impulses through the myocardium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyponatremia: Does not typically cause prominent P wave changes; its ECG manifestations are less specific and often involve general effects on conduction and contractility.

 

Note - Hyponatremia is usually silent on the ECG

 

Option C. Hypocalcemia: Associated with prolonged QT interval due to an elongation of the ST segment but not with pseudo P pulmonale.

 

Option D. Hypercalcemia: Typically presents with a shortened QT interval and shortened ST segment, differing significantly from the changes seen in hypokalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: All of the following criteria are used for assessing the severity of acute pancreatitis, except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. ROME Criteria

 

Explanation:

 

ROME Criteria is not used for assessing the severity of acute pancreatitis. The validated scoring systems for severity assessment in acute pancreatitis include Ranson, Glasgow (Imrie's), APACHE, SAPS, SOFA, MODS, and modified Marshall scoring systems. Additional tools include the BISAP Score and CT Severity Index. ROME Criteria is used for functional gastrointestinal disorders, not for assessing pancreatitis severity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ranson Criteria - This is a valid severity assessment tool for acute pancreatitis. It uses 11 parameters (5 at admission and 6 at 48 hours), with a score ≥3 indicating severe pancreatitis. Parameters include age, white blood cell count, blood glucose, LDH, AST at admission and hematocrit fall, BUN rise, arterial oxygen, calcium levels, base deficit, and fluid sequestration at 48 hours.

 

Option B. APACHE-II - This is a valid severity assessment tool used in intensive care settings for pancreatitis patients. It assesses physiological parameters and can be calculated at any time during hospitalization, making it more dynamic than Ranson criteria.

 

Option C. Imrie's Criteria - Also known as the Glasgow scoring system, this is a valid severity assessment tool similar to Ranson but with fewer parameters. It also uses a cutoff of ≥3 to indicate severe pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Severity stratification in acute pancreatitis should be performed using validated scoring systems (Ranson, Glasgow/Imrie, APACHE, BISAP, CT Severity Index) to identify patients at risk for persistent organ failure and complications.

choices.text: Rapid filling of the left ventricle

questions.text: The dicrotic notch on the aortic pressure curve is caused by?  (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Closing of the aortic valve

 

Explanation: 

 

The dicrotic notch is a small oscillation or wave that appears in the falling phase of the aortic pressure curve during the cardiac cycle. This notch is specifically caused by vibrations set up when the aortic valve snaps shut. The dicrotic notch occurs at the end of ventricular systole when the aortic pressure exceeds left ventricular pressure, causing the aortic valve to close. This closure creates a brief backward movement of blood and subsequent rebound, generating the characteristic notch in the aortic pressure tracing.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Closing of the mitral valve The mitral valve closes at the beginning of ventricular systole, not during the falling phase of aortic pressure. Mitral valve closure contributes to the first heart sound (S1) and occurs before ejection of blood into the aorta, so it cannot be responsible for the dicrotic notch.
  • Option B. Closing of the tricuspid valve The tricuspid valve closes at the beginning of right ventricular systole, similar to mitral valve closure. It has no direct effect on aortic pressure and occurs much earlier in the cardiac cycle than the dicrotic notch.
  • Option D. Rapid filling of the left ventricle Rapid filling of the left ventricle occurs during early diastole, after the aortic valve has closed. This ventricular filling phase follows the dicrotic notch rather than causing it, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dicrotic notch is a distinctive feature on the aortic pressure curve that specifically marks the moment of aortic valve closure at the end of ventricular systole, representing the transition between systole and diastole.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with chronic hepatitis B presents with right upper quadrant pain, weight loss, jaundice, and a palpable liver edge. His laboratory results show elevated liver enzymes and significantly raised AFP levels. Imaging reveals a hypoechoic liver lesion with arterial enhancement and early washout. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC)

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests HCC, supported by:

 

  • Risk factor: Chronic hepatitis B
  • Clinical symptoms: RUQ pain, weight loss, jaundice, hepatomegaly
  • Lab findings: Elevated liver enzymes and significantly raised alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)
  • Imaging: Hypoechoic lesion with arterial enhancement and early washout, classic for HCC

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cholangiocarcinoma: More commonly associated with PSC, liver flukes, or biliary disease

 

Option C. Focal nodular hyperplasia: Usually incidental, benign, seen in young women

 

Option D. Hepatic adenoma: More common in young women on OCPs, lacks early washout

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatocellular carcinoma presents with characteristic imaging (arterial enhancement with early washout) in a patient with chronic hepatitis B.

questions.text: This condition is treated by supplementation of which of the following? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nicotinamide

 

The condition shown in the image is pellagra, which is characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, often referred to as the "three Ds" of pellagra. Pellagra is caused by a deficiency of niacin (vitamin B3) or its precursor, tryptophan. Nicotinamide is the form of niacin that is typically used in supplementation to treat pellagra. Niacin supplementation helps replenish the body's stores of this essential nutrient and alleviates the symptoms associated with the deficiency. The hallmark sign in the image is the "casal necklace," a symmetrical, hyperpigmented rash around the neck, which is typical of pellagra.

 

Note –

 

If with this clinical scenario like Pellagra with an increase in xanthurenic acid in urine, it indicates that the niacin deficiency is likely due to a Vitamin B6 deficiency. In such cases, Vitamin B6 supplementation is recommended for the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency leads to symptoms such as night blindness and xerophthalmia, not the symptoms seen in pellagra.

 

Option C. Vitamin E: Vitamin E is an antioxidant and its deficiency is associated with neurological problems, but it is not related to the symptoms of pellagra.

 

Option D. Vitamin C: Vitamin C deficiency causes scurvy, characterized by bleeding gums and petechiae, which is unrelated to the condition seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, is treated with niacin or nicotinamide supplementation

questions.text: Which vector is responsible for transmitting Rickettsia Tsutsugamushi? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mites.

 

Rickettsia Tsutsugamushi is the causative agent of scrub typhus, a type of rickettsial disease. The primary vector responsible for transmitting Rickettsia Tsutsugamushi is the trombiculid mite, commonly known as a chigger. These mites are parasitic larvae that bite humans and other animals, transmitting the bacteria through their saliva during feeding.

 

Scrub typhus is prevalent in areas with dense scrub vegetation, hence the name. Rodents often serve as the reservoir hosts for the bacteria, maintaining the infection cycle in nature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Louse: Lice are vectors for other rickettsial diseases, such as epidemic typhus (Rickettsia prowazekii), but not for scrub typhus.

 

Option C. Flea: Fleas are vectors for diseases like murine typhus (Rickettsia typhi) but are not involved in the transmission of scrub typhus.

 

Option D. Ticks: Ticks transmit various rickettsial diseases, including Rocky Mountain spotted fever (Rickettsia rickettsii), but not scrub typhus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scrub typhus, caused by Rickettsia Tsutsugamushi, is transmitted by the trombiculid mite, making mites the vector responsible for this disease.

questions.text: A patient present with gum bleeding, petechiae, poor wound healing, and other related symptoms. Which of the following vitamin deficiencies is most likely responsible for this presentation? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin C

 

The clinical features described are classic signs of Vitamin C deficiency (Scurvy)

 

  • Gum bleeding and inflammation
  • Petechiae (due to capillary fragility)
  • Poor wound healing
  • These occur because Vitamin C is essential for: 
  1. Collagen synthesis - hydroxylation of proline and lysine
  2. Maintaining blood vessel integrity
  3. Wound healing

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A (Incorrect)

 

  • Deficiency presents with: 
    • Night blindness (earliest symptom)
    • Bitot's spots (most specific)
    • Xerophthalmia
    • Keratomalacia

 

Option B. Vitamin B6 (Incorrect)

 

  • Deficiency presents with: 
    • Neurological symptoms
    • Seborrheic dermatitis
    • Glossitis
    • Convulsions in infants

 

Option C. Vitamin B3 (Incorrect)

 

  • Deficiency leads to Pellagra characterized by 4Ds: 
    • Dermatitis (photosensitive)
    • Diarrhea
    • Dementia
    • Death

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Classic triad of scurvy (Vitamin C deficiency): gum bleeding, poor wound healing, and petechiae/easy bruising. Understand that these symptoms occur due to impaired collagen synthesis and compromised blood vessel integrity.

questions.text:
Erythropoietin is produced by: (INICET MAY 2024)

 

  1. Kidney
  2. Liver
  3. Spleen
  4. Lung
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 2

 

Explanation:

 

Erythropoietin is a hormone primarily produced by the kidneys and to a lesser extent by the liver. In a healthy individual, the majority of erythropoietin (approximately 90%) is produced by the kidney, specifically by peritubular interstitial fibroblasts. These cells respond to hypoxia (low oxygen levels) by increasing the production of erythropoietin, which then stimulates the bone marrow to produce more red blood cells. The liver also contributes to erythropoietin production, particularly through sinusoidal cells, although it accounts for only about 10% of the hormone's production under normal conditions.

 

In certain pathological conditions, such as in some types of anemia (e.g., thalassemia major), the spleen may take on a role in erythropoietin production to compensate for the body's increased need for red blood cells. However, this is not the case in healthy individuals, which is why the spleen and other organs like the lung are not considered significant sources of erythropoietin under normal physiological conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

3 and 4: While the spleen can contribute in pathological states, it is not a primary source under normal conditions, and the lung does not contribute to erythropoietin production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythropoietin is primarily produced by the kidneys, with the liver contributing to a lesser extent. Understanding the primary and secondary sources of erythropoietin is crucial, particularly in the context of conditions affecting red blood cell production.

questions.text: Which structure does not pass through the foramen ovale? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: a) Middle meningeal artery

 

Explanation:

The middle meningeal artery does not pass through the foramen ovale. Instead, it enters the cranial cavity through the foramen spinosum, which is located posterolateral to the foramen ovale in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. The middle meningeal artery is a branch of the first part of the maxillary artery that supplies the dura mater and bones of the cranial cavity. It is clinically significant because its rupture can cause extradural hemorrhage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option b) Lesser petrosal nerve - This nerve passes through the foramen ovale. It carries preganglionic parasympathetic fibers from the tympanic plexus to the otic ganglion.

 

Option c) Mandibular nerve - This is the third division of the trigeminal nerve (V3) which exits the skull through the foramen ovale to enter the infratemporal fossa.

 

Option d) Accessory meningeal artery - This artery passes through the foramen ovale along with the mandibular nerve and lesser petrosal nerve.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The foramen ovale transmits the mandibular nerve (V3), lesser petrosal nerve, and accessory meningeal artery, while the middle meningeal artery passes through the foramen spinosum.

questions.text:
Which of these are the components of high-quality CPR? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

a) Compression rate 100-120/min

b) Depth of compression in adults is 3-4 cm

c) Ventilation of 2 breaths for every 30 compressions

d) Allow complete chest recoil
questions.solution:
Ans. D) a, c & d

 

High-quality CPR in adults requires several critical components to be effective. These include:

 

a. Compression Rate: The compression rate should be between 100-120 compressions per minute. This rate is optimal to maintain blood flow during cardiac arrest.

 

b. Depth of Compression: For adults, the correct depth of compression is at least 2 inches (approximately 5 cm). The depth mentioned in the option B (3-4 cm) is incorrect as it is insufficient to generate adequate blood flow.

 

c. Ventilation: The recommended ventilation ratio is 2 breaths for every 30 compressions if no advanced airway is in place. This ensures adequate oxygenation during CPR.

 

d. Chest Recoil: Allowing complete chest recoil after each compression is essential. This allows the heart to refill with blood between compressions, which is crucial for effective circulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For high-quality CPR in adults, ensure a compression rate of 100-120/min, a compression depth of at least 2 inches (5 cm), a ventilation ratio of 30:2, and allow complete chest recoil between compressions.

questions.text: Most common hernia in females (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Indirect inguinal hernia

 

The most common type of hernia in females is the inguinal hernia, and specifically, the indirect inguinal hernia. This can be confusing because femoral hernias are indeed more common in females compared to males, but the indirect inguinal hernia remains the most prevalent overall in females.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct inguinal hernia: Incorrect. While inguinal hernias are common, the direct inguinal hernia is less common than the indirect inguinal hernia in both males and females.

 

Option C. Femoral hernia: Incorrect. Femoral hernias are more frequently seen in females compared to males, but they are not the most common type of hernia in females overall.

 

Option D. Obturator hernia: Incorrect. Obturator hernias are rare and not the most common type of hernia in females.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In females, the most common type of hernia is the indirect inguinal hernia, despite femoral hernias being more common in females compared to males.

 

Incidence of Hernia in Females: Indirect inguinal Hernia > Direct inguinal Hernia > Femoral hernia

questions.text: Which condition is associated with the appearance of Brown sign? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glomus tumor

 

Explanation: 

 

The Brown sign (also called pulsation sign) is specifically associated with glomus tumors. This sign is characterized by pulsation of the mass in the middle ear that can be observed through the tympanic membrane. Glomus tumors (paragangliomas) are highly vascular neoplasms that originate from paraganglionic tissue. Their vascularity results in visible pulsations that characterize the Brown sign.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Meniere's disease: This is characterized by endolymphatic hydrops with symptoms of episodic vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness. It is not associated with any visible pulsating mass or the Brown sign as it affects the inner ear rather than producing a middle ear mass.

 

Option C. Acoustic neuroma: This is a benign tumor of the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII) that typically presents with unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and sometimes vertigo. It develops in the internal auditory canal or cerebellopontine angle, not in the middle ear, and does not present with visible pulsations or Brown sign.

 

Option D. Otosclerosis: This is characterized by abnormal bone formation around the stapes footplate, leading to progressive conductive hearing loss. It does not present with a visible pulsating mass or Brown sign. The otoscopic findings in otosclerosis are typically normal or may show a pinkish hue through the tympanic membrane (Schwartze sign).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Brown sign (pulsation sign) refers to visible pulsations of a middle ear mass seen through the tympanic membrane and is pathognomonic for glomus tumors due to their highly vascular nature.

questions.text: Hecht's Pneumonia is typically associated with which of the following infections? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Measles 

 

Explanation: 

 

Hecht's pneumonia refers to the giant cell pneumonia that occurs as a complication of measles infection. It is characterized by the presence of multinucleated giant cells (Warthin-Finkeldey cells) in the lung tissue, which are pathognomonic for measles. This form of pneumonia represents a serious complication of measles and is associated with significant morbidity and mortality. Measles virus directly infects the respiratory epithelium, leading to necrosis and the formation of these characteristic giant cells in the lungs.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Malaria - Incorrect. Malaria is a parasitic infection caused by Plasmodium species transmitted by mosquitoes. While it can cause pulmonary complications (particularly P. falciparum), it does not cause Hecht's pneumonia or the formation of multinucleated giant cells in the lungs.

 

Option C. RSV - Incorrect. Respiratory Syncytial Virus causes bronchiolitis and pneumonia, especially in young children, but is not associated with Hecht's pneumonia or giant cell formation. RSV typically causes inflammation of the bronchioles with mucus plugging and epithelial cell necrosis.

 

Option D. Pneumococcus - Incorrect. Streptococcus pneumoniae is a common bacterial cause of community-acquired pneumonia in all age groups, but causes a lobar pneumonia pattern with neutrophilic infiltration, not giant cell pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hecht's pneumonia (giant cell pneumonia) is a specific and severe complication of measles infection, characterized by the pathognomonic Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells in lung tissue, and represents one of the serious complications that can occur with measles.

questions.text: Which of the following comes under ASA grade 1?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Healthy patient

 

The American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) Physical Status Classification System is a system used to assess the fitness of patients before surgery. It classifies patients into six different categories based on their overall health:

 

  • ASA 1: A Normal, healthy patient with no systemic disease and no significant medical problems.
  • ASA 2: A patient with mild systemic disease that does not limit physical activity (e.g., mild asthma or controlled hypertension).
  • ASA 3: A patient with severe systemic disease that limits activity but is not incapacitating (e.g., uncontrolled diabetes or hypertension).
  • ASA 4: A patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life (e.g., unstable angina, advanced COPD).
  • ASA 5: A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without surgery (e.g., massive trauma, ruptured aneurysm).
  • ASA 6: A brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes.

 

In this classification, ASA grade 1 is designated for a healthy patient with no significant medical problems.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mild disease: Incorrect because this describes an ASA grade 2 patient, who has a mild systemic disease that is under control and does not significantly impact their overall health.

 

Option C. Moderate disease: Incorrect because this describes an ASA grade 3 patient, who has a moderate to severe systemic disease that limits their activity.

 

Option D. Morbid patient: Incorrect because this describes an ASA grade 5 patient, who is moribund and at a high risk of death without surgical intervention.

 

Educational Objective:


ASA grade 1 refers to a normal, healthy patient with no comorbidities or systemic diseases.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Ataxia Telangiectasia is NOT true? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Selective absence of IgM

 

Ataxia Telangiectasia is associated with IgA deficiency, not selective IgM deficiency. These children may have IgA deficiency or impaired cell mediated immunity, frequent sinopulmonary infections and increased predisposition to lymphoreticular malignancies. Immunological abnormalities are common in Ataxia Telangiectasia, but specifically IgA deficiency is mentioned, not IgM deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Premature ageing - This is a correct statement about Ataxia Telangiectasia, which is characterized by premature aging and is classified as a progeroid syndrome.

 

Option C. Insulin-dependent Diabetes Mellitus - This is a correct statement as higher incidence of diabetes mellitus is associated with Ataxia Telangiectasia. The text specifically mentions there is a higher incidence of diabetes mellitus in patients with Ataxia Telangiectasia.

 

Option D. Progressive Cerebellar Ataxia - This is a correct statement and is the hallmark feature of Ataxia Telangiectasia. The disease is characterized by progressive cerebellar ataxia starting at 1-3 years.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Ataxia Telangiectasia typically presents with progressive cerebellar ataxia, telangiectasia of the conjunctiva and skin, elevated alpha-fetoprotein levels, and immunodeficiency (specifically IgA deficiency and impaired cell-mediated immunity), along with increased risk of malignancy and diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child with muscle wasting and skinny appearance. Which of the following condition best fit the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Marasmus

 

Marasmus is a form of severe malnutrition characterized by energy deficiency. A child with marasmus typically has a very thin, wasted appearance due to the loss of muscle mass and subcutaneous fat. This condition results from inadequate intake of calories and protein over a prolonged period. In the context of the question, the 4-year-old child with muscle wasting and a skinny appearance aligns with the clinical presentation of marasmus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kwashiorkor: (Fatty baby/ anasarca) This condition is also a form of severe malnutrition but is primarily due to protein deficiency rather than a total calorie deficiency. Children with kwashiorkor often appear with edema, an enlarged liver, and a swollen abdomen. They may have a more plump appearance due to fluid retention, not a skinny one.

 

Option C. Stunting: This term refers to chronic malnutrition that results in reduced growth rate and height for a child's age. While stunted growth is a sign of malnutrition, it does not specifically account for the muscle wasting and extreme thinness described in the question.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect as marasmus directly fits the description provided in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marasmus is characterized by severe wasting of muscle and subcutaneous fat, leading to a very thin, emaciated appearance in affected children.

questions.text: A young girl presented with a history of multiple episodes of loss of consciousness that lasted for 5-10 minutes. These episodes occur only in front of family members and only in the daytime. The patient can recall the conversation that happened around her during these episodes; there is no history of tongue bite and no incontinence. What is the preferred treatment? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Treat with behavioral therapy

  

The patient's symptoms—episodes of apparent loss of consciousness only occurring in front of family members, during the day, with the ability to recall surrounding conversations—suggest that these are not true seizures but pseudoseizures, which are commonly associated with conversion disorder.

 

Conversion disorder is characterized by neurological symptoms without a medical or neurological cause, often triggered by psychological factors.

 

Behavioral therapy is the preferred treatment for conversion disorder. This approach helps the patient address and modify the underlying psychological factors contributing to their symptoms through techniques such as cognitive restructuring, relaxation techniques, and coping strategies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Treat with aversive therapy: Aversive therapy involves applying unpleasant stimuli to reduce the occurrence of undesirable behaviors. It is considered unethical, especially in treating psychological disorders like conversion disorder, because it can cause harm and does not address the underlying psychological issues.

 

Option C. Valproate: Valproate is an antiepileptic medication used to treat true seizures, but it is not appropriate for conversion disorder or pseudoseizures since the condition is psychological rather than neurological.

 

Option D.  Ketogenic diet: The ketogenic diet is sometimes used to manage epilepsy but is not suitable for conversion disorder. The diet has no role in addressing psychological origins of symptoms like pseudoseizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The preferred treatment for conversion disorder, which manifests with pseudoseizures, is behavioral therapy, not antiepileptic drugs or other seizure management strategies.

questions.text: In which of the genetic material, Number of Adenine will not be equal to that of Thymine:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HIV

 

The questions is related to genetic material of different organisms or viruses and their base pairing rules. In DNA, adenine (A) always pairs with thymine (T), and cytosine (C) always pairs with guanine (G). However, in RNA, which is the genetic material of some viruses like HIV, thymine is replaced by uracil (U) in base pairing. So, in RNA, adenine pairs with uracil.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E. coli (Escherichia coli): E. coli is a bacterium, and its genetic material is DNA. In DNA, adenine pairs with thymine, so the number of adenine is equal to the number of thymine.

 

Option B. Mitochondrial DNA of humans: Mitochondrial DNA is also composed of DNA, and in DNA, adenine pairs with thymine. Therefore, the number of adenine is equal to the number of thymine.

 

Option D. Herpes virus: Herpes viruses have dsDNA as their genetic material, so adenine pairs with thymine in their DNA. Thus, the number of adenine is equal to the number of thymine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) is a retrovirus with RNA as its genetic material. In RNA, adenine pairs with uracil. So, the number of adenine will not be equal to that of thymine.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best indicator of some dehydration in SAM? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Urine output, Thirst & oral mucosa

 

Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) in children can present as either Kwashiorkor or Marasmus. These conditions cause the child to appear very thin and emaciated, making it challenging to rely on typical physical signs like skin pinch or sunken eyeballs for dehydration assessment. SAM children, especially those with Marasmus, already have a "baggy pant" appearance and very thin skin, making these signs unreliable.

 

The most reliable indicator of dehydration in SAM children is assessing urine output, thirst and the condition of the oral mucosa:

 

  • ⁠Urine output, thirst: If the child eagerly drinks water, it indicates some dehydration. Refusal to drink or feed may suggest severe dehydration.
  • ⁠Oral mucosa: Checking the dryness of the oral mucosa is a practical and reliable method. In SAM children, if the oral mucosa is dry, it indicates dehydration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Skin pinch: This option is incorrect because SAM children already have very thin skin, making skin pinch an unreliable indicator.

 

Option B. Sunken eyeballs: This option is incorrect as SAM children naturally have sunken eyeballs due to severe weight loss and malnutrition, making this sign unreliable for detecting dehydration.

 

Option D. Absent tears: this indicator is not the best indicator. It can be seen in some as well as severe dehydration cases. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In SAM children, the best indicators of dehydration are urine output, the dryness of the oral mucosa and the child's thirst.

questions.text: Which of the following factors can decrease iron absorption? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tea

 

Tea, especially black tea, contains compounds called tannins. Tannins can bind to iron, making it harder for the body to absorb. Therefore, drinking tea, especially with meals, can decrease the absorption of iron.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin C: Vitamin C, also known as ascorbic acid, actually enhances iron absorption, especially non-heme iron (the form of iron found in plant-based foods). It does this by converting iron into a form that is more easily absorbed by the body.

 

Option C. Sprouts: Sprouts, like other plant-based foods, contain phytates (phytic acid), which can bind to minerals like iron and inhibit their absorption. However, the process of sprouting reduces the phytate content, which may actually improve the availability of iron.

 

Option D. Gastric Acid: Gastric acid is crucial for iron absorption as it helps convert iron into its ferrous (Fe2+) form, which is more easily absorbed. Reduced gastric acid can lead to decreased iron absorption, as seen in conditions like atrophic gastritis or with the use of certain medications (like proton pump inhibitors).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tea, particularly due to its tannin content, is known to decrease iron absorption. The other options, Vitamin C and gastric acid, typically aid in iron absorption, while sprouts, although containing phytates, have reduced phytate levels due to the sprouting process and are not the primary dietary concern for iron absorption inhibition

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presents to the ER with menorrhagia. She mentions that her father and sister also suffer from bleeding disorders. Which of the following is likely? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Von Willebrand Disease

 

Von Willebrand Disease (vWD) is the most likely diagnosis given the family history of bleeding disorders and the patient's presentation with menorrhagia. vWD is an autosomal dominant condition affecting both males and females, characterized by defective platelet function due to a deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor. This leads to symptoms such as prolonged bleeding, menorrhagia, and prolonged bleeding after dental extractions or surgeries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factor X deficiency: An extremely rare autosomal recessive condition that typically presents with joint bleeding (hemarthrosis) and intramuscular hematomas, which are more indicative of coagulation disorders rather than bleeding tendencies seen in platelet disorders.

 

Option B. Factor VIII deficiency: Known as Hemophilia A, this is an X-linked recessive disorder affecting mostly males. Females are typically carriers and rarely show symptoms. Hemophilia A presents with severe bleeding episodes and hemarthrosis, not usually menorrhagia.

 

Option C. Factor IX deficiency: Known as Hemophilia B, this is also an X-linked recessive disorder affecting mostly males, with similar presentations to Hemophilia A, including severe bleeding episodes and hemarthrosis, not typically menorrhagia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Von Willebrand Disease is an autosomal dominant disorder presenting with bleeding symptoms like menorrhagia and is more common in females compared to Hemophilia A or B, which are X-linked recessive and primarily affect males.

questions.text: Lagophthalmos is caused by defect in: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 7th cranial nerve

 

Lagophthalmos is the inability to close the eye completely. This condition is caused by a defect in the 7th cranial nerve (facial nerve). The facial nerve innervates the orbicularis oculi muscle, which is responsible for closing the eyelid. When this nerve is damaged or dysfunctional, it leads to weakness or paralysis of the orbicularis oculi, resulting in incomplete eyelid closure.

 

 

Note - It's important to distinguish between "lagophthalmos" (inability to close the eye) and "lid lag" (where the eyelid doesn't follow the eyeball's movement properly), as both involve "lag" but refer to different phenomena and are caused by different underlying issues.

 

Lid Lag occurs when the eyelid fails to follow the downward movement of the eyeball when shifting from an upward gaze to a straight or downward gaze. This condition is noticeable in thyroid eye disease and is associated with von Graefe's sign.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3rd cranial nerve: The oculomotor nerve innervates the levator palpebrae superioris muscle, which is responsible for raising the upper eyelid. A defect in this nerve would cause ptosis (drooping eyelid) rather than lagophthalmos.

 

Option B. 4th cranial nerve: The trochlear nerve innervates the superior oblique muscle of the eye, which is involved in eye movement. It is not directly related to eyelid function.

 

Option C. 6th cranial nerve: The abducens nerve innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which is responsible for lateral eye movement. It does not control eyelid function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lagophthalmos is caused by a defect in the 7th cranial nerve (facial nerve), which innervates the orbicularis oculi muscle responsible for eyelid closure

choices.text: During palpation, over the left hypochondrium

questions.text: A 6-week-old infant is brought to the clinic with a history of projectile vomiting and poor weight gain. Physical examination reveals an abdominal mass in the epigastrium, and the diagnosis of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is suspected. An abdominal mass in a patient with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is best seen? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. During feeding

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) is a condition where the pylorus becomes hypertrophied and thickened. This leads to gastric outlet obstruction and symptoms such as projectile vomiting, dehydration, and electrolyte imbalances.

 

True. During feeding, or immediately after, the thickened muscle of the pylorus might be most palpable. As the stomach tries to empty its contents through the narrowed pylorus, the hypertrophied muscle can contract and become more prominent. This is called the "olive-like mass" which is palpable in the epigastrium to the right of the midline. This sign is pathognomonic for CHPS. The act of feeding induces peristaltic waves in the stomach, making the pyloric mass more prominent and easier to palpate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Soon after birth: CHPS typically presents in the third to fifth week of life, although it can be present at birth. It is rare to palpate the mass immediately after birth. The symptoms usually progress, and the hypertrophic pylorus becomes more palpable as the condition worsens.

 

Option C. During palpation, over the left hypochondrium: The pylorus is located on the right side of the abdomen, so palpating the left hypochondrium wouldn't help in detecting a mass related to CHPS.

 

Option D. During palpation, over the epigastrium: While the hypertrophied pyloric muscle can indeed be felt in the epigastrium, its palpability becomes much more distinct during or after feeding due to the reasons mentioned in option A. The epigastrium is the upper central region of the abdomen and is the location where the "olive-like mass" of CHPS is most frequently palpated.

 

Educational Objective:


In congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, the characteristic "olive-like mass" is most easily palpated during or immediately after feeding when the stomach contracts against the hypertrophied pyloric muscle.

questions.text: Calculate the mid parental height of a male patient with father height 183 cm and mother height 175 cm? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 185.5

 

The mid-parental height (MPH) is a method used to estimate the potential adult height of a child based on the heights of the parents.

 

Formula:

 

Using the given heights:

 

  • Father's height = 183 cm
  • Mother's height = 175 cm
  • MPH = [(183+175)/2] + 6.5 = 185.5

 

Therefore, the mid-parental height is 185.5 cm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To calculate the mid-parental height for a male child, use the formula:

 

(Father’s height+Mother’s height)/2+6.5 cm.

questions.text: Which nerve is responsible for innervating the cremaster muscle? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: b. Genitofemoral nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The cremaster muscle receives its motor innervation from the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve (L1). The cremaster muscle consists of muscle fasciculi embedded in the cremasteric fascia. These fasciculi form superficial loops from the middle one-third of the upper surface of the inguinal ligament and deep loops from the pubic tubercle, pubic crest, and conjoint tendon. The muscle is fully developed only in males and forms a sac-like cremasteric fascia around the spermatic cord and testis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iliohypogastric nerve - This nerve (L1) supplies the skin of the anterior abdominal wall and becomes cutaneous about 2.5 cm above the superficial inguinal ring. It does not innervate the cremaster muscle.

 

Option C. Obturator nerve - This nerve supplies the adductor muscles of the thigh and provides sensory innervation to the medial aspect of the thigh. It has no role in innervating the cremaster muscle.

 

Option D. Femoral nerve - This nerve supplies the anterior compartment muscles of the thigh and provides sensory innervation to the anterior thigh and medial leg. It does not supply the cremaster muscle.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The cremaster muscle, which can elevate the testis and helps close the superficial inguinal ring during increased intra-abdominal pressure, is innervated by the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve (L1) and its reflex contraction (cremasteric reflex) indicates the integrity of the L1 spinal segment.

choices.text: Forced expiration against a closed glottis
Forced expiration against an open glottis
Forced inspiration against a closed glottis

questions.text: Which of the following occur during the beginning cough reflex? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Forced expiration against a closed glottis

 

The cough reflex begins with a forced expiration against a closed glottis. The pressure builds up in the lungs and, when the glottis opens, it allows for a rapid expulsion of air to clear the airways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Forced expiration against an open glottis: This does not occur during a cough reflex. While the glottis does eventually open to allow air to be expelled, the characteristic high-pressure expulsion of air is the result of the closed glottis after which it opens.

 

Option C. Forced inspiration against a closed glottis: Inspiration occurs with an open glottis. A closed glottis would prevent air from entering the lungs, so this does not occur during the cough reflex.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect because option (a) accurately describes an event that occurs during the cough reflex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The beginning of the cough reflex involves a forced expiration against a closed glottis, building up pressure in the lungs which is then rapidly released when the glottis opens.Top of Form

questions.text: Which of the following are the first permanent teeth to erupt in children? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A. First Molar

 

The first permanent teeth to erupt in children are the first molars. According to the developmental milestone. the first permanent teeth to appear are the first molars at around 6-7 years of age. This is specified in the section on dentition which states: "1st Permanent Teeth to appear: 1st Molar (6 yr)." The eruption of the first permanent molar typically occurs before the eruption of permanent incisors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. First Premolar - Incorrect because the first premolars erupt later in the sequence of permanent dentition, usually around 10-11 years of age according to the dentition table. They come after the permanent incisors and first molars have already erupted.

 

Primary dentition - Mnemonic – IIMCM

 

 

Permanent teeth - Mnemonic - Mom is in pain, Papa can make medicine.

 

 

Option C. Lateral Incisor - Incorrect because permanent lateral incisors erupt at around 8-9 years of age (upper) and 7-8 years (lower), after the eruption of central incisors which appear at 7-8 years (upper) and 6-7 years (lower).

 

Option D. Canine - Incorrect because permanent canines erupt even later, at around 11-12 years of age (upper) and 10-12 years (lower), well after the first molars, incisors, and premolars have erupted.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The first permanent teeth to erupt in children are the first molars at approximately 6-7 years of age, often called the "6-year molars," which erupt before the shedding of primary teeth begins.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Tuberculosis of the Hip during the Stage of Synovitis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Apparent Lengthening

 

In the stage of synovitis (Stage I) of tuberculosis of the hip, there is effusion into the joint which demands the hip to be positioned for maximum capacity. This position is one of flexion, abduction, and external rotation. Due to the pelvic tilt compensating for the abduction deformity, the pelvis tilts downwards on the affected side, which creates an apparent lengthening of the limb. However, when true limb lengths are measured, both limbs are equal. This stage is therefore also called the "stage of apparent lengthening" and lasts for a very short period.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flexion, Abduction, Internal Rotation - This is incorrect because in Stage I (synovitis), the hip assumes a position of flexion, abduction, and external rotation. Internal rotation typically occurs in Stage II (arthritis) when muscle spasm develops.

 

Option B. Flexion, Adduction, External Rotation - This is incorrect because during synovitis, the position is flexion, abduction, and external rotation. Adduction deformity develops later in Stage II when articular cartilage involvement leads to muscle spasm.

 

Option D. True Shortening - This is incorrect for Stage I. True shortening occurs in Stage III (stage of erosion) when there is actual destruction of bone. In Stage I, there is apparent lengthening with equal true limb lengths.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

TB Hip Stage I (synovitis) presents with the hip in flexion, abduction, and external rotation, resulting in apparent lengthening due to downward pelvic tilt compensating for abduction deformity, while true limb lengths remain equal.

questions.text: All of the following are features of Ganser Syndrome, except: (Neet PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Verbigeration. 

 

Explanation:


Ganser syndrome is a rare dissociative disorder most notable for the presence of "approximate answers"—a symptom known as vorbeigehen. Patients respond with incorrect but closely related answers that suggest an understanding of the question.

 

The syndrome is also commonly associated with:

 

Clouding of consciousness: manifesting as disorientation, confusion, amnesia, and impaired reality testing.

 

Hallucinations: often visual or auditory, occurring in many cases.

 

Somatic conversion symptoms: such as non-neurologic analgesia, shifting sensory deficits, or other functional neurologic signs sometimes described as "hysterical stigmata."

 

Verbigeration is a senseless repetition of one or several sentences or phrases. For example, a patient continued to repeat the following sentences for hours “Life is amazing. God is great. Children will come to meet soon. Its not a feature of Ganser’s syndrome 

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Approximate Answers: This is actually the defining feature of Ganser syndrome. These nearly correct but inaccurate responses distinguish the condition.
  • Option B. Clouding of consciousness: A core component of Ganser syndrome. It often contributes to the presentation of confusion and impaired insight.
  • Option C. Somatic conversion: Often seen in Ganser syndrome, especially in the form of conversion symptoms like numbness, non-anatomic sensory changes, or motor deficits that don’t follow neurologic patterns.

 

Educational Objective:


Ganser syndrome is best remembered by its hallmark triad:

  1. Approximate answers (vorbeigehen)
  2. Clouding of consciousness
  3. Hallucinations
     It may also present with conversion symptoms, but verbigeration is not part of the typical clinical picture and is more aligned with psychotic disorders like schizophrenia.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient with a history of hyperlipidemia was started on statins for elevated triglyceride levels. Despite the statin therapy, his triglyceride levels remain persistently elevated at over 600 mg/dL. Which of the following medications should be administered next to help manage his triglyceride levels? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gemfibrozil

 

Gemfibrozil belongs to the class of drugs known as fibrates. Fibrates are particularly effective in lowering triglyceride levels, which is critical in this patient’s case given the significantly elevated triglyceride level over 600 mg/dL. This level puts the patient at increased risk of developing pancreatitis, a serious and potentially life-threatening condition. Fibrates, such as gemfibrozil, work by activating peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-alpha (PPAR-alpha), which increases the oxidation of fatty acids and decreases triglyceride levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ezetimibe: This medication works by inhibiting the absorption of cholesterol in the intestines. It is primarily used to lower LDL cholesterol and has a minimal effect on triglyceride levels. It would not be effective in this scenario where significant triglyceride lowering is needed.

 

Option B. Niacin: Niacin, also known as vitamin B3, is effective in increasing HDL cholesterol but is less effective than fibrates in lowering triglycerides. It is not the first choice in managing severe hypertriglyceridemia like in this case.

 

Option D. Evolocumab: Evolocumab is a PCSK9 inhibitor used primarily to lower LDL cholesterol, especially in patients with homozygous familial hypercholesterolemia. It is not indicated for the treatment of elevated triglycerides and would not be effective in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with significantly elevated triglyceride levels (over 600 mg/dL) that do not respond adequately to statins, fibrates like gemfibrozil are the next step in management to reduce the risk of pancreatitis.

questions.text: Bilateral pedal edema is least likely to be associated with which of the following?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic venous insufficiency

 

Bilateral pedal edema is often due to systemic conditions that lead to fluid retention or increased pressure in the veins.

 

Chronic venous insufficiency, typically results from conditions like deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which is more likely to cause unilateral (one-sided) pedal edema due to localized obstruction of venous return. While chronic venous insufficiency can sometimes cause bilateral edema, it is less common compared to the other conditions listed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chronic renal failure: Patients with chronic renal failure cannot excrete excess fluid properly, leading to fluid retention and generalized edema, including in both legs.

 

Option C. Congestive heart failure: Heart failure results in increased venous pressure and fluid retention, which typically causes dependent edema, including bilateral pedal edema.

 

Option D. Chronic liver disease: Liver disease can lead to hypoalbuminemia and reduced oncotic pressure, causing generalized and bilateral pedal edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic venous insufficiency is least likely to be associated with bilateral pedal edema compared to chronic renal failure, congestive heart failure, and chronic liver disease.

 

Edema results from imbalances in:

 

  1. Hydrostatic pressure (↑ in heart failure)
  2. Oncotic pressure (↓ in liver/kidney disease)
  3. Lymphatic drainage
  4. Capillary permeability

 

Summary Table:

questions.text: Which value is derived in ABG?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bicarbonate

 

Explanation:

 

In arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis, pH, pO2 (partial pressure of oxygen), and pCO2 (partial pressure of carbon dioxide) are measured directly by the ABG machine.

 

Bicarbonate (HCO3-) is not directly measured but is derived using the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation. The equation relates the pH, pCO2, and bicarbonate concentration, enabling the calculation of bicarbonate from the directly measured values of pH and pCO2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. pH: This is directly measured in ABG analysis using an electrode sensitive to hydrogen ions.

 

Option B. pO2: This is directly measured in ABG analysis using an oxygen-sensitive electrode.

 

Option C. pCO2: This is directly measured in ABG analysis using a carbon dioxide-sensitive electrode.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In arterial blood gas analysis, bicarbonate (HCO3-) is the value that is derived, not directly measured, using the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation.

questions.text: Identify the cell shown in the image. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Purkinje cell


Purkinje cells are large, flask-shaped neurons located in the cerebellar cortex. The image clearly demonstrates a Purkinje cell with its prominent size, distinctive flask-shaped soma, and its arrangement within the cerebellum. These cells are crucial for cerebellar function as they integrate excitatory and inhibitory inputs to modulate motor coordination and balance. They are positioned in the Purkinje cell layer, sandwiched between the molecular layer and the granular layer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Basket cell: Incorrect.Basket cells are inhibitory interneurons found in the molecular layer of the cerebellum. They are smaller and have dendritic arbors that do not resemble the prominent flask-shaped soma of Purkinje cells.

 

Option B. Stellate cell: Incorrect. Stellate cells are also located in the molecular layer and are smaller interneurons with star-like dendritic arbors. They lack the unique morphology of Purkinje cells.

 

Option D. Golgi cell: Incorrect. Golgi cells are found in the granular layer of the cerebellum and are larger interneurons but do not have the flask-shaped soma characteristic of Purkinje cells.

 

Educational Objective:


Purkinje cells are large, flask-shaped neurons located in the Purkinje layer of the cerebellum. They play a critical role in motor coordination by integrating multiple inputs and sending inhibitory signals to the cerebellar nuclei.

questions.text: All are true regarding intracellular receptors except: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Fastest acting receptors

 

Explanation:


Intracellular receptors operate through a relatively slow mechanism that involves hormone entry into the cell, binding to cytoplasmic or nuclear receptors, translocation to the nucleus (if initially in cytoplasm), binding to DNA, and ultimately altering gene transcription and protein synthesis. This process typically takes hours to produce physiological effects, making intracellular receptors among the slowest, not fastest, signaling pathways in the body.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Act by regulating gene expression: This is a true characteristic of intracellular receptors. Once activated by their ligands, intracellular receptors bind to specific DNA sequences (hormone response elements) and regulate transcription of target genes.
  • Option c. Glucocorticoid receptors: This is a correct example of intracellular receptors. Glucocorticoid receptors reside in the cytoplasm and, upon binding with their steroid hormone ligands, translocate to the nucleus to modulate gene expression.
  • Option d. DNA contains hormone responsive elements: This is accurate. Hormone responsive elements (HREs) are specific DNA sequences that serve as binding sites for hormone-receptor complexes, allowing for targeted gene regulation by various hormones.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Intracellular receptors function primarily through genomic mechanisms by regulating gene transcription, a process that requires hours to manifest physiological effects, in contrast to membrane-bound receptors which can initiate cellular responses within seconds through non-genomic pathways.

questions.text: Calcium binds to which one of the following proteins in smooth muscle contraction? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calmodulin

 

In smooth muscle cells, calcium plays a crucial role in initiating muscle contraction, similar to its role in skeletal muscle cells. However, the proteins that interact with calcium to start the contraction process are different in these two muscle types.

 

In skeletal muscle cells, calcium binds to troponin, which is part of the troponin-tropomyosin complex that regulates the interaction of actin and myosin, leading to muscle contraction. However, in smooth muscle cells, the contraction mechanism does not involve troponin.

 

In smooth muscle, when calcium ions enter the cell, they bind to a protein called calmodulin. This calcium-calmodulin complex then activates an enzyme called myosin light chain kinase (MLCK). Activated MLCK phosphorylates the myosin light chains, leading to conformational changes in myosin heads that allow them to interact with actin filaments, thereby causing muscle contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Actin: Actin is a structural protein that forms filaments and interacts with myosin during muscle contraction. However, calcium does not bind directly to actin in smooth muscle to initiate contraction.

 

Option C. Tropomyosin: Tropomyosin is a regulatory protein associated with actin filaments, but in smooth muscle, it does not play the same role in calcium binding as it does in skeletal muscle.

 

Option D. Troponin: Troponin is the protein to which calcium binds in skeletal muscle to initiate contraction. However, troponin is absent in smooth muscle, so it cannot be the correct answer for smooth muscle contraction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In smooth muscle cells, calcium binds to calmodulin to initiate muscle contraction, unlike in skeletal muscle where calcium binds to troponin.

questions.text: According to wound ballistics, A gunshot wound showing burning, blackening, tattooing around the wound, can be classified as: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Close shot entry wound

 

Burning (heat of the gases), blackening (deposition of soot) and tattooing (unburned powder particles embedding into the skin) are the features of entry wound. They are not found in exit wound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Close shot exit wound: Exit wounds do not show burning, blackening, or tattooing. They are usually larger and more irregular than entry wounds.

 

Option C. Distant shot entry wound: Distant shot entry wounds do not exhibit burning, blackening, or tattooing. They show a clean entry hole.

 

Option D. Distant shot exit wound: Exit wounds from distant shots also do not show these features and are typically larger and more irregular.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Entry Wound features:

 

  1. Contact Shot: Burning, blackening and tattooing present just on the margin; not around the wound. Very minimally visible.
  2. Close Shot: Burning, blackening and tattooing present in large amount around the wound (esp. blackening is prominent)
  3. Intermediate Range: Only Tattooing present around the wound
  4. Distant range: None of these present around the wound.
